currency.currencyDescription: The Currency used in this system are small metal coins consisting of bronze, silver, and gold. The value of a coin is also equal to the intrinsic value of the metal itself. This results in different currencies being widely accepted across civilization, although the coinage might be different. The following coins are common in the Realm.

coinDescriptions.name: Bronze Coin
coinDescriptions.description: The lowest currency mostly made out of copper. Mostly used for buying food or basic necessities

coinDescriptions.name: Silver Coin
coinDescriptions.description: Worth 10 copper coins, used for the larger purchases in daily live such as tools or trade goods

coinDescriptions.name: Gold Coin
coinDescriptions.description: Worth 100 Bronze Coins or 10 Silver Coins, mostly used by merchants, nobles and adventurers

currency.coinValueDescription: Every coin weighs 5 grams. While the metal of the coin also holds intrinsic value that roughly equates the the monetary value. During different time periods and region that value can differ more or less. It is also important that currency comes in different sizes as well. For example there are heavier cc weighing 50 g that are worht 10 regular bc. However only the basic units are tracked

itemTierDescription:
Items have an associated Tier and Skill. The Item Tier determines the required the skill rank for identifying and crafting those items and the Skill describes the Tool, Lore or Regular Skill required for this task.
The Item Tiers are not associated with the character [LEVEL] or the abilities to use those items. However it is not recommended for characters to have items 2 tiers higher than their character [LEVEL] since it might significantly affect game balance.
equippingItemsDescription: When you get an item it is assumed that you store it in a backpack or similar container or wear it on your body. For wearing and carrying items there are the following rules restrictions:
wearingAndCarryingItemsRules: If the total weight you carry exceeds your permitted weight you suffer penalties which depends on your [STR] as can be seen in the Carrying Capacity table below.
There are no rules restrictions for sizes of items but the players and the GM should agree what makes sense.
You can not wield more than one item in each hand.
You can only wear one set of armor.
carryingCapacityDescription: Carrying capacity represent how much weight you can carry while travelling which increases with your [STR] according to the Table below. For every additional 5 kg (rounded up) you carry above your carrying limit, you suffer a cumulative Penalty to the following:
liftPushDragDescription: Lift/Push/Drag represents how much weight you can well lift, push, drag in short bursts, useful for moving obstacles or knocking over objects with an object interaction which increases with your [STR] according to the Table below. These unlike carrying capacity are not hard values and can be modified by circumstance or a [STR] [ATTRIBUTE TEST] determined by the GM.
